# Chief Intelligence Officer - Daily Brief
**Topic**: Latest global political and military news
**Time**: 2026/1/31 16:47

## Situation Overview
Welcome to the Daily News Channel, I'm Joe. It's January 31, 2026, and welcome to today's Daily News. In the past 24 hours, the global political and security situation has undergone dramatic changes, with multiple crises intertwined. First, the much-anticipated US federal budget bill was officially put into partial shutdown at the last minute due to the House of Representatives' failure to reach an agreement, undoubtedly casting a shadow over President Trump's administration. Meanwhile, in the international diplomatic arena, Trump's hardline stance on the sovereignty of Greenland has triggered a strong backlash from European allies, with French President Macron announcing the deployment of additional military forces to Greenland. In the Middle East, the situation between the US and Iran is on the brink of war due to the approach of a large fleet and Iran's live-fire exercises; while in East Asia, political dialogue and maritime friction coexist in the South China Sea, reflecting the complexity of great power rivalry. Today, we will delve into these core news stories concerning global stability. Please see the detailed report below.

## Key Intelligence
### The U.S. federal government has officially declared a partial shutdown due to a budget impasse.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: Bloomberg, TBS News
- **Summary**: According to the latest news received by this station, the US federal government officially entered a partial shutdown in the early hours of January 31st local time because Congress failed to pass several key spending bills before Friday's midnight deadline. Bloomberg reported that although the Senate had previously passed the bills by a large majority, they failed to be enacted due to the early departure of House members from Washington. President Trump had previously warned that the shutdown would limit the functions of several government agencies. Currently, the White House is urging lawmakers to return on Monday and reconsider the bills to minimize their impact on the operation of the country. This deadlock reflects the serious domestic political challenges Trump faces during his term.
- **References**:
  - [1] Bloomberg: https://www.bloomberg.com/feeds/sitemap_news.xml
  - [2] TBS News: https://www.tbsnews.net/worldbiz/usa/us-government-starts-likely-brief-shutdown-house-fails-approve-deal-1348516

### Trump says Putin agreed to suspend airstrikes on Kyiv during the cold snap.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Taipei Times, YouTube
- **Summary**: According to the Taipei Times, US President Trump revealed on Thursday that Russian President Putin had agreed to his personal request to suspend military attacks on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities during the extreme cold snap in Ukraine (temperatures expected to drop to -30 degrees Celsius). Trump emphasized on social media that this mediation achievement demonstrated his initiative in de-escalating the Russia-Ukraine conflict. However, defense experts remain cautious, noting indications that Russia is still using certain navigation systems for reconnaissance. Ukraine, on the other hand, stated that it will closely monitor whether Russia truly fulfills its commitments and guard against potential precision strikes by its drones.
- **References**:
  - [1] Taipei Times: https://www.taipeitimes.com/
  - [2] YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tlp6LvIba8Q

### Greenland sovereignty sparks diplomatic rift: France and Denmark jointly increase troop presence to counter Trump's threats.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: France 24, NYT, Wikipedia
- **Summary**: The sovereignty issue of Greenland is escalating into a diplomatic storm. According to a report in The New York Times, in response to President Trump's recent threats regarding Greenland's territorial sovereignty, French President Macron announced after a defense meeting that France would deploy additional military forces to Greenland in support. The Danish government followed suit, announcing the deployment of a large number of troops. Although the North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD) described its aircraft deployment in the region as "routine coordination," at such a sensitive time, leaders of several European countries are accelerating discussions on how to reduce their dependence on the United States, marking a further deterioration in transatlantic relations between the US and Europe.
- **References**:
  - [1] The New York Times: https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/31/world/europe/eu-trump-greenland-europe.html
  - [2] Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/January_2026

### Tensions between the US and Iran escalate sharply: Trump dispatches a large fleet to pressure Iran.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: CBS News, Anadolu Agency, Iran Gov
- **Summary**: According to multiple sources, the Middle East is facing its most tense moment in decades. President Trump announced that an "invincible fleet," led by the USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier, is sailing towards the Strait of Hormuz, issuing an ultimatum to Iran demanding its return to nuclear negotiations. In response, Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps announced a two-day live-fire exercise in international waterways. The U.S. Central Command has issued a stern warning, stating that it will not tolerate any provocations against U.S. troops or merchant ships. Currently, countries such as New Zealand have urgently evacuated diplomats from Tehran, and the international community is closely monitoring whether direct military conflict will break out in the region.
- **References**:
  - [1] Anadolu Agency: https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/us-will-not-tolerate-unsafe-actions-by-irans-revolutionary-guard-corps/3815983
  - [2] Iran Gov: https://irangov.ir/detail/476753

### The US representative warned Iran at the United Nations that it would not rule out using military means to stop the repression.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: UN Press, CBS News
- **Summary**: At the latest UN meeting, the US representative issued a rare and strongly worded statement. According to CBS News, in response to the Iranian government's recent violent crackdown on protesters, the US made it clear that Washington has put "all options," including military intervention, on the table to stop the so-called "massacre." The Security Council heard testimony from several journalists and dissidents who had been victimized during the meeting. Currently, Tehran's human rights record has drawn significant international attention, and the US is attempting to exert pressure through multiple channels to force the Iranian authorities to cease their violence against their citizens.
- **References**:
  - [1] UN Press: https://press.un.org/en/content/security-council

### Venezuelan crisis escalates: Death toll from US airstrikes rises to 80
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: Wikipedia, Indian Express, CBS News
- **Summary**: According to data compiled from Wikipedia and CBS News, the ongoing US airstrikes on Venezuela have resulted in at least 80 deaths, including 32 Cuban citizens. This casualty figure has triggered a strong reaction from Cuba, which has declared two days of national mourning. Meanwhile, Venezuelan politics are in turmoil, with acting president Rodriguez speaking by phone with Indian Prime Minister Modi seeking diplomatic support. Opposition leader Machado reiterated his intention to formally assume the presidency at the appropriate time. The US Department of Justice is currently applying to the court to postpone deportation proceedings against Venezuelan immigrants due to the security situation.
- **References**:
  - [1] Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/January_2026
  - [2] Indian Express: https://indianexpress.com/news-sitemap.xml

### Dramatic political change in Syria: Newly elected President Shahraim visits the White House and receives US support.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: South China Morning Post
- **Summary**: The situation in Syria has taken a dramatic turn. According to the South China Morning Post, Syrian President El Shaarawy recently paid an official visit to Washington and met with Trump. This move marks a complete shift in US policy towards Syria, with the US indicating it will lift sanctions and support the new Syrian government. Furthermore, Syria has formally announced its joining the international coalition against ISIS. However, the local security situation remains precarious. Recently, US forces in Syria suffered their first deadly ambush since Assad's fall, resulting in the deaths of two US soldiers. Trump subsequently vowed severe retaliation.
- **References**:
  - [1] SCMP: https://www.scmp.com/topics/islamic-state

### Russia and Ukraine complete the largest body exchange since 2025.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: Wikipedia, Reuters, BBC
- **Summary**: According to a Reuters report from Brussels, Russia and Ukraine completed their first large-scale exchange of remains of fallen soldiers on January 31, since November 2025. In this exchange, Russia received 38 sets of remains, while Ukraine received as many as 1,000 sets. Simultaneously, the EU again pressured Russia on the financial regulatory front, formally adding it to its financial blacklist due to money laundering risks. This move will further sever Russia's ties with European financial markets. These actions demonstrate that despite humanitarian contact, the hostile relationship between the two sides is deepening.
- **References**:
  - [1] Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/January_2026
  - [2] Reuters: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/January_2026

### Nuclear control treaties face expiration crisis: The countdown to the expiration of the US-Russia New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START)
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Reuters, NYT, Bloomberg
- **Summary**: A key agreement maintaining global nuclear strategic stability is on the verge of collapse. According to Reuters, the New START Treaty, the last nuclear arms reduction agreement between the US and Russia, is set to expire on February 5, 2026, and the two sides have yet to reach any agreement on an extension. Arms control experts told Bloomberg that once the treaty expires, the 50-year-old bilateral nuclear constraint mechanism will come to a complete end, potentially triggering a new round of global nuclear arms race. Currently, several international organizations are urgently calling on the Trump administration to commit to continuing to adhere to nuclear arms quotas in order to maintain basic strategic stability.
- **References**:
  - [1] Bloomberg: https://www.bloomberg.com/feeds/sitemap_news.xml
  - [2] Reuters: https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2026-01-30/explainer-what-is-the-new-start-nuclear-treaty-and-why-does-its-expiry-matter

### The situation in the South China Sea is becoming increasingly complex: dialogue between China and the Philippines in Cebu coexists with maritime friction.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: The Manila Times, Philstar, Global Times
- **Summary**: According to the Manila Times and the Global Times, representatives from China and the Philippines recently resumed political dialogue in Cebu after a year-long hiatus, engaging in frank exchanges on the Code of Conduct (COC) in the South China Sea. However, diplomatic efforts failed to mask the tense situation at sea. China accused the Philippines of "delusional infringement" during its exercises at Scarborough Shoal, while the Philippines claimed its aircraft were subjected to close-range interference from Chinese helicopters during its mission. As the new chair of ASEAN, the Philippines reiterated its hope to complete COC negotiations by 2026 despite existing differences and its firm commitment to upholding freedom of navigation in the South China Sea.
- **References**:
  - [1] The Manila Times: https://www.manilatimes.net/2026/01/31/news/china-resume-talks-to-ease-tensions/2268386
  - [2] Global Times: https://www.globaltimes.cn/china/diplomacy/

### China vows to purge its military of "corrupt officials": severely punish those who illegally embezzle military funds.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Bloomberg, SCMP
- **Summary**: According to reports from Bloomberg and the South China Morning Post, the Chinese government is intensifying its anti-corruption purge within the military, focusing on cracking down on "parasites" who illegally embezzle military funds. Two senior generals have recently been investigated for suspected corruption. The reports analyze that against the backdrop of escalating strategic competition, China is strengthening the auditing and control of military budgets to ensure the effective use of resources. This move is seen by the outside world as the latest signal of Chinese leaders' deep-seated rectification of internal problems within the People's Liberation Army, aiming to enhance the substantive combat effectiveness of the troops by strengthening integrity.
- **References**:
  - [1] Bloomberg: https://www.bloomberg.com/feeds/sitemap_news.xml
  - [2] SCMP: https://www.scmp.com/topics/us-china-relations

### Taiwan publicly displays attack drones for the first time to deter mainland China.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Bloomberg
- **Summary**: According to the latest news obtained by this station, the Taiwanese military recently publicly showcased its newly developed swarm of attack drones for the first time. Bloomberg reported that this move aims to demonstrate Taiwan's asymmetric warfare capabilities, creating a substantial deterrent against mainland China by strengthening its low-cost, high-efficiency strike methods. The demonstration covered various types of autonomous attack systems, showcasing Taiwan's latest achievements in military technology autonomy. Defense analysts believe that with the widespread adoption of drone technology, the military balance in the Taiwan Strait is undergoing subtle but significant changes.
- **References**:
  - [1] Bloomberg: https://www.bloomberg.com/feeds/sitemap_news.xml

### The U.S. Indo-Pacific Command strengthens cyber defense cooperation with Taiwan, Japan, and the Philippines.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Taipei Times
- **Summary**: According to a report in the Taipei Times, citing Joshua Rudd, Vice Commander of the U.S. Indo-Pacific Command, the U.S. military is currently engaged in comprehensive cybersecurity cooperation with Taiwan, Japan, and the Philippines on a daily basis. Rudd stated that the U.S. military has dispatched liaison officers to these key allies to jointly address cyber threats targeting the Indo-Pacific region through joint exercises and ongoing technical interactions. This move is seen as part of the U.S. "Integrated Deterrence" strategy, aimed at significantly enhancing collective defense against regional aggression and cyber infiltration through multilateral cooperation.
- **References**:
  - [1] Taipei Times: https://www.taipeitimes.com/

### Japan and the Philippines signed a reciprocal defense agreement; the US expanded its base in Kenya to strengthen its global presence.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: The Defense Post, AP, Wikipedia
- **Summary**: In the realm of global defense cooperation, several important agreements were reached in the past 24 hours. According to the Associated Press, Japan and the Philippines have formally signed a defense cooperation agreement, allowing them to mutually provide ammunition, fuel, and food aid without tariffs. Meanwhile, in Africa, the Pentagon announced it will expand its military base in Kenya to enhance its security response capabilities in East Africa. Furthermore, the US government approved a $1.7 billion contract to upgrade Spanish frigates. These flurry of military agreements reflect the accelerating formation and strengthening of defense alliances by various countries against the backdrop of volatile geopolitics.
- **References**:
  - [1] The Defense Post: https://thedefensepost.com/2026/01/30/spain-f100-frigate-upgrade/
  - [2] AP: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/January_2026

### Trump threatens to impose a 50% tariff on Canadian aircraft.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Bloomberg, Outlook India
- **Summary**: The flames of trade protectionism are once again rising in North America. According to Bloomberg, US President Trump recently issued a strong trade warning to Canada, threatening to impose a 50% tariff on all aircraft imported from Canada. Furthermore, the Trump administration is pushing to revoke the US market approval for certain Canadian aircraft models. This statement has triggered high alert in Canada and caused volatility in financial markets. Analysts point out that this is the strongest signal against a neighboring country in Trump's second administration's tariff plan, potentially triggering a new round of US-Canada trade war and impacting the global aviation supply chain.
- **References**:
  - [1] Bloomberg: https://www.bloomberg.com/feeds/sitemap_news.xml
  - [2] Outlook India: https://www.outlookindia.com/

### Trump declares state of emergency over Cuba: imposes tariffs on oil trade.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: UPI, Wikipedia
- **Summary**: According to UPI news agency, US President Trump has declared a national emergency regarding Cuba. The core of this policy is to impose high punitive tariffs on all countries that supply oil to Cuba, aiming to completely cut off Cuba's energy supply lines. Cuban Foreign Minister Rodriguez subsequently issued a stern statement condemning the move as a "comprehensive fuel blockade." This is seen as a continuation of the Trump administration's "maximum pressure" strategy in Latin America, potentially pushing Cuba's already fragile economy to the brink of collapse. International reactions to this decision, which could lead to a humanitarian crisis, have been mixed.
- **References**:
  - [1] UPI: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events

### G7 foreign ministers' summit supports Middle East ceasefire plan: condemns Russian attack on Ukrainian energy facilities.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Mirage News, WAM, US State Department
- **Summary**: At the G7 foreign ministers' summit in Niagara, the G7 issued a joint statement reaffirming its common position on several global hotspots. According to the US State Department website, the G7 foreign ministers strongly condemned Russia's attack on Ukraine's energy infrastructure and announced their full support for President Trump's comprehensive plan to end the Gaza conflict. On the Middle East issue, all parties unanimously urged Iran to fulfill its nuclear non-proliferation obligations and resume full cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency. Furthermore, the G7 reiterated the importance of maintaining order in the Indo-Pacific region and opposed any attempt to unilaterally change the status quo by force.
- **References**:
  - [1] Mirage News: https://www.miragenews.com/g7-foreign-ministers-statement-niagara-summit-1569389/

### The Gaza ceasefire agreement faces fragile challenges: the US approves massive arms sales to Israel and Saudi Arabia.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: SCMP, Indian Express, National Herald India
- **Summary**: Despite the Gaza ceasefire agreement entering its crucial second phase, violence continues. According to the South China Morning Post, recent Israeli airstrikes in Gaza have killed at least five people. Surprisingly, at this critical juncture, the US government approved the sale of advanced weaponry worth $16 billion to Israel and Saudi Arabia. UN Secretary-General Guterres has urgently called for the full implementation of the ceasefire and demanded the complete withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. This contradictory signal of supporting a ceasefire while simultaneously offering arms sales has raised questions within the international community about the feasibility of lasting peace in the Middle East.
- **References**:
  - [1] SCMP: https://www.scmp.com/topics/collections/government-public-services-ngos
  - [2] National Herald India: https://www.nationalheraldindia.com/international/israeli-strikes-persist-in-gaza-killing-five-despite-ceasefire

### Crisis escalates in Sahel region: US orders evacuation of embassy staff in Niger
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Zagazola, Anadolu Agency
- **Summary**: Security risks in West Africa and the Sahel are spiraling out of control. According to the security website Zagazola, following the rapid deterioration of the situation after the attack on Niger's Niamey airport, the US State Department has officially ordered the immediate evacuation of non-essential embassy staff and their families. Niger's military junta leader, Chiani, has publicly accused France and other countries of funding terrorism, leading to heightened hostility in the region. In neighboring Nigeria, Boko Haram recently launched a devastating attack, killing at least 25 workers. The evacuation of diplomatic personnel by multiple countries is further exacerbating the security vacuum and humanitarian risks in the region.
- **References**:
  - [1] Zagazola: https://zagazola.org/index.php/breaking-news/sahel-tensions-escalate-after-niamey-airport-attack-as-tchiani-accuses-france-benin-and-cote-d-ivoire-of-sponsoring-the-attack

### Terrorist attacks hit multiple parts of India: Delhi Red Fort bombing kills 13
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: Indian Express, CBS News, National Herald
- **Summary**: According to the Indian Express, India has recently suffered several deadly terrorist attacks. A car bomb exploded near the famous Red Fort in Delhi, killing 13 people and injuring more than 30. Indian police are conducting a large-scale investigation under the Prevention of Unlawful Activities Act. In the Kashmir region, fierce fighting broke out between security forces and militants, resulting in the death of one soldier. To facilitate the operation, authorities have cut off mobile internet access in the area. Furthermore, reports indicate that popular tourist destinations in Kashmir have also been attacked, resulting in serious casualties. India has been placed on high alert nationwide.
- **References**:
  - [1] Indian Express: https://indianexpress.com/news-sitemap.xml
  - [2] National Herald: https://www.nationalheraldindia.com/national/red-fort-blast-delhi-police-invoke-uapa-to-examine-role-of-busted-faridabad-module

### Bangladesh issues security warning as general election approaches: Security heightened on India-Bangladesh border.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: Indian Express, TripAdvisorIndia
- **Summary**: According to reports from our correspondent in Southeast Asia, Bangladesh is scheduled to hold general elections on February 12th. The interim government has issued a stern security warning to guard against extremist attacks targeting polling stations. As a result, the United States and other countries have issued travel warnings. Meanwhile, the Indian Border Force (BSF) has also mobilized, using the latest electronic reconnaissance equipment to strengthen patrols along the India-Bangladesh border, guarding against terrorist infiltration and election-related transnational crimes. The political turmoil in Bangladesh ahead of the election has drawn significant attention from neighboring countries regarding potential refugee influxes and security threats.
- **References**:
  - [1] Indian Express: https://indianexpress.com/news-sitemap.xml

### Domestic political developments in Britain and India: Shah vows to purge infiltrators, Badnoch does not rule out election cooperation.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: Indian Express, ITV
- **Summary**: In India and the UK, domestic political forces are undergoing dramatic upheavals. According to the Indian Express, Indian Home Minister Amit Shah recently delivered a strong speech, vowing to eliminate any infiltrators within the country should he win the general election. Meanwhile, in the UK, Conservative Party leader Kemi Badnoch, amidst the Welsh parliamentary elections, publicly stated that he did not rule out the possibility of reaching an electoral cooperation agreement with the Reform Party to counter pressure from the ruling party. These statements from key political figures in both countries demonstrate that nationalist and right-wing political forces are undergoing rapid reorganization in the post-pandemic era, which will have a profound impact on the domestic political landscape of these nations.
- **References**:
  - [1] Indian Express: https://indianexpress.com/news-sitemap.xml
  - [2] ITV: https://www.itv.com/news/wales/2026-01-30/badenoch-refuses-to-rule-out-deal-with-reform-in-welsh-senedd-election

### Panama's Supreme Court ruled that the operating rights of Hong Kong-owned terminals were unconstitutional: This will impact China's canal development strategy.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Taipei Times
- **Summary**: According to the Taipei Times, the Panamanian Supreme Court issued a strategically significant ruling on January 29, declaring the Panama Canal port concession held by a subsidiary of Hong Kong's CK Hutchison Holdings unconstitutional. This ruling is widely seen as a major success for US foreign policy, aimed at weakening China's influence over the Panama Canal, a globally strategic waterway. With the ruling in effect, the ownership of the terminal's operation will once again enter a phase of international competition. This is not merely a dispute over a commercial contract, but a microcosm of the power struggle among major powers at a crucial geopolitical juncture.
- **References**:
  - [1] Taipei Times: https://www.taipeitimes.com/

### Vietnam and the United States hold trade negotiations: Propose zero tariffs on key goods
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: The Investor
- **Summary**: Vietnam is actively strengthening its economic and trade ties with the United States. According to *The Investor*, Vietnam has proposed to the US that certain Vietnamese goods entering the US market receive zero tariffs during the upcoming sixth round of trade negotiations. Despite Washington's extremely high demands for market access, Vietnam remains committed to deepening the strategic partnership between the two countries. Meanwhile, due to fluctuations in US tax policy, some solar energy companies with Chinese investment have announced the suspension of production in Vietnam. This trend indicates that Vietnam is striving to solidify its trade advantages with the US through diplomatic means amidst the complex restructuring of global supply chains.
- **References**:
  - [1] The Investor: https://theinvestor.vn/foreign-firms-in-vietnam-struggle-to-recruit-workers-jetro-survey-d18284.html

### NATO is spending $1 billion to build a "drone wall" to deter Russian threats.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Bloomberg
- **Summary**: In response to growing border threats, European countries are launching an ambitious defense plan. According to Bloomberg, NATO members have reached a $1 billion agreement to build a high-density "drone wall" along their borders with Russia. This system will integrate state-of-the-art surveillance and electronic warfare technologies to counter Russian airspace violations and infiltration in real time. Analysts point out that this marks a significant step forward for Europe in asymmetric warfare defense and reflects NATO countries' heightened awareness of Russia's "hybrid warfare" strategy.
- **References**:
  - [1] Bloomberg: https://www.bloomberg.com/feeds/sitemap_news.xml

### Trump's nomination of Warsh to head the Federal Reserve triggered volatility in the gold and silver markets.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: Forbes, Indian Express
- **Summary**: The US financial world has undergone a major personnel shake-up. President Trump recently formally nominated Kevin Warsh to be the new Chairman of the Federal Reserve. According to Forbes, this announcement caused significant volatility in global gold and silver markets, with investors widely believing that Warsh's policy proposals may be more radical than the current chairman's. Simultaneously, the US Department of Justice released over 3 million pages of files related to the Jeffrey Epstein case, including extensive FBI investigation records. These two bombshells have once again brought the issues of political and financial transparency in the US to the forefront of public discussion.
- **References**:
  - [1] Forbes: https://www.forbes.com/news_sitemap.xml
  - [2] Indian Express: https://indianexpress.com/news-sitemap.xml

### Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi implements expansionary policies to address financial turmoil.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Japan Times, Bloomberg
- **Summary**: According to The Japan Times, Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi is actively pursuing a large-scale fiscal expansion policy in an attempt to solidify public support ahead of the House of Representatives election. However, this policy direction has led to the yield on Japanese 10-year government bonds reaching a near-century high. Data from the Ministry of Finance shows that despite depreciation pressure on the yen, Japan has not directly intervened in the foreign exchange market in the past four weeks. Takaichi has also recently held intensive meetings with US and South Korean officials, attempting to mitigate domestic financial risks by strengthening geopolitical alliances amidst Japan's waning regional influence. This risky economic move by Japan has drawn significant attention from the International Monetary Fund.
- **References**:
  - [1] Japan Times: https://www.japantimes.co.jp/
  - [2] Bloomberg: https://www.bloomberg.com/feeds/sitemap_news.xml

### Global defense budgets surge: AI and autonomous weapon systems enter a period of deep integration
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Forbes, GlobeNewswire
- **Summary**: According to a recent Forbes analysis, global defense spending is projected to surge by trillions of dollars this year. The report highlights that the U.S. military is accelerating the integration of autonomous solutions such as HavocAI into existing weapon platforms to address AI communication challenges in complex adversarial environments. Furthermore, various new types of equipment, including tethered drones, are gradually entering the military aftermarket. This shift towards physical AI and autonomous warfare signifies a rapid evolution in future warfare from traditional human-powered confrontations to technology-driven, intelligent battlefields, and has also driven the continued strength of related technology stocks.
- **References**:
  - [1] Forbes: https://www.forbes.com/news_sitemap.xml
  - [2] GlobeNewswire: https://www.globenewswire.com/en/Newsroom/GoogleSitemap

### Davos 2026: Geopolitical conflict listed as the top global risk of the year
- **Time**: 2026-01-29
- **Source**: World Economic Forum
- **Summary**: At the recently opened 2026 World Economic Forum in Davos, geopolitical risks were at the heart of the agenda. According to a report released by the forum, armed conflict between nations has been listed as the top risk this year. The report warns that due to the proliferation of AI-driven disinformation and increasing polarization in global society, current international instability has reached its highest level since the Cold War. Political and business leaders from around the world are discussing how to find new mechanisms for economic and security cooperation in the context of receding globalization to prevent potential systemic collapse.
- **References**:
  - [1] World Economic Forum: https://www.weforum.org/stories/2025/07/why-asean-must-transform-global-tensions-into-regional-opportunities/

### The UN Security Council urgently extended several resolutions in response to the period of frequent global conflicts.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: UN News, Security Council Report
- **Summary**: According to our correspondent at the United Nations headquarters, the Security Council recently adopted Resolution 2812, extending the reporting mechanism on Houthi attacks on merchant ships in the Red Sea for another six months. UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres warned at the meeting that the current number of global conflicts has reached its highest point since World War II. In addition to the situation in the Middle East, the Security Council also focused on the security of the Haitian elections, the terrorist attacks in Afghanistan, and the humanitarian crisis in Darfur, Sudan. Guterres urged major powers to avoid unilateral actions, emphasizing that the dominance of a single power would increase the risk of global instability, and called for a return to multilateral diplomacy to resolve crises.
- **References**:
  - [1] UN News: https://press.un.org/en/content/security-council
  - [2] Security Council Report: https://www.securitycouncilreport.org/atf/cf/%7B65BFCF9B-6D27-4E9C-8CD3-CF6E4FF96FF9%7D/2026_01_forecast.pdf
